reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I CANNOT believe that I just spent $400 for a room that barely even fit the "queen" sized bed we requested (it felt more like a full-sized). My husband and I could barely be in the room together at the same time with our luggage - there was nowhere to put it! There weren't enough towels for one person, let alone two, and there was no fan or exhaust system in the bathroom - so when you took a shower, the hotel room was also steamy. To make things worse, there is no coffee maker in the room - and it took me 5 calls to room service to even order my $8 "pot" (about 2 cups worth) of coffee. If we were going to be in town for more than one night, I would have left - TOO SMALL!
reviews.title: Shockingly bad hotel-waste of money!

likes.disliked: — Price, size of room, lack of service

There's something down-to-earth about all the staff we encountered, and the hotel doesn't try too hard to be cool or hip, it's just a great little friendly place.
reviews.title: Back Again!

likes.liked: — I liked the rooms and the value.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I was initially concerned, okay, down-right scared, about how small the rooms were going to be, especially because we had booked such a great rate. But upon check-in (during the Labor Day weekend no less) we were upgraded to a twin size room when asked if it were available. We did take a look at the other rooms, they vary in size and shape, and yes, there are two very small rooms that basically are just a few feet larger than the bed. But there are two places in this world where space is always cramped, and that's Manhattan and Tokyo. So just be prepared and brace yourself for smaller-than-usual rooms.
reviews.title: small room, poor service = unhappy guests

likes.liked: — Small room, poor service, general attitude of staff

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The free wi-fi was a definite plus, there is also a LAN line in the room for those who prefer it. The last time I stayed at the Westin we paid $15 per day for internet, and it's like that in a lot of the chain hotels. A bit of a warning for those who need lobby ambiance and such: it's pretty small and has just about enough space for a few different parties to wait around. This didn't bother us one bit, and I was almost glad that they didn't waste a lot of money on the lobby and instead put it to good use in the guestrooms. We loved the H2O bath products as other guest mentioned. Come and stay here as soon as you can, it's been my experience that a lot of small hotels will start off with high end bath amenities, but when it comes to cutting costs, these are the first to go as they switch to less expensive generic brands.
reviews.title: 5 days of Mela
I done good!
reviews.text: Not knowing what to expect having never visited New York, we were pleasantly surprised by Hotel Mela. The price was very affordable for mid Manhattan in summer ($221/night) and the rooms were lovely. Location was everthing and allowed us to walk or take the subway to most everything. We hit 9th Ave. amost everynight to eat, affortable, walkable and just enough off the tourist beat to have great food and interesting folks. We booked the king sized bed and I believe one step up from the regular room. It was small, but suited our purposes beautifully. Well until we discovered the water leak in the bathroom, but before we could even moan over our misfortune the staff has us whisked away to another room, an upgrade and it was delightful. Walls a little thin, so if you are going to be upset by the crying child, yes we heard them, then not the place for you. But who goes to New York to spend much time in their room and frankly not sure how long the poor kid cried as we were in our rooms to sleep or long enough to have a beverage, nap, shower and out again. The Hotel Mela was wonderfully clean, met my white tissue standard. It may not fare well over the years as it is an older building, but as long as the staff continue to keep it as clean as it was when we were there, it's a definite must.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: After reading all the reviews on this hotel, I knew this was going to be better than my first visit to NY city (I previously stayed at comfort suites). Hotel Mela was just half a block awhile from Times Squares and a few blocks from Bryant Park making it a great location. The hotel desk was busy when we first arrived at 8AM and I wasn't expecting our room to be ready. To our surprise they had a room ready and we were able to shower and nap. Our room was clean and nice (we had a superior) with a surprisingly good sized bathroom (had a bathtub with a window seat). During the night our AC failed to work and had to sleep with windows open to get the air flowing within the room. The next morning we informed the front desk that our AC was not working and a repairman was sent up. He suggested to the front desk that we be moved to another room. To our suprise we were upgraded to an executive junior suite! It was lovely with a sitting room and a larger bed. I definitely would recommend and return to Hotel Mela!
reviews.title: Wonderful experience!
Absolutely LOVED The Mela
reviews.text: I stayed at The Mela over the 2007 Christmas period (5 days). I booked two rooms, one for me and the hubby, the other for my family. I had an absolutely fabulous time! I couldn't recommend this place more.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Rates were reasonable, in fact extremely so for the "middle of it all" location. Rooms while small were neatly configured to provide a desk and arm chair in a separated area--perfect when one guest wants to sleep while another reads or works without disturbing the sleeper. Though staff were besieged by guests who needed extended accommodation due to the Iceland volcano ash, they remained calm and did what they could to help everyone out. They responded quickly to our request to fax something and to install a new light bulb in the reading lamp. I've seen complaints about the size of the lobby, and it is small, but unless you're trying to keep a party of 10 together, it isn't a real problem. Decor is modern without feeling cold. While there are no in-house dining facilities, there's a small, charming French restaurant right next store that serves a nice breakfast and appeared to be doing well for lunch and dinner. The bar is pleasant and compensates for the modest lobby of the hotel if you need to wait to meet someone. There is also a charming Italian restaurant about 3 doors down on the other side of the hotel from the French restaurant and a couple of other places we didn't even have time to investigate right across the street.
reviews.title: Great Place

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2010, traveled with family
reviews.text: The place is pleasant, convenient, well-run and an all around find. We recommend it enthusiastically.

Location of room was towards rear of building - must be quieter there as negative reviews have mentions noisy street level rooms. It can't hurt to ask for rear, high floor. Also, be sure to check the travelzoo website to find very nice discounted rates on this and other hotels in the area. We stopped at the ‘Bistro’ right next door for late night cocktails and were sorry we didn’t have dinner there – nice menu and ambiance although a wee bit pricey.

reviews.text: Spent a week at The Mela in late May. Rooms tiny but very comfortable and stylish, though given the free wifi a desk area would have been helpful. Excellent and reasonably priced minibar service including large basket of goodies, replenished daily. Housekeeping excellent. Sadly our view was of a derelict wall and there was a ventilation fan outside which was somewhat noisy but really, how much time do you spend in a New York hotel room? Bathroom also compact but well kitted out. Air conditioning excellent and reception staff very helpful (we had to move three times on arrival - first room non-smoking, second next to a very noisy generator) and nothing was too much trouble. Location good but a bit near the mania of Times Square for my liking though to others this may be ideal. The bistro next door is excellent. I would stay again but would perhaps go for the extra cost of a larger room.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed January 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Though Hotel Mela is smack in the middle to Times Square, the hotel was quiet and comfy. We decided on a room one step above the standard room for a king size bed and a little extra room - and it was still less than $200 per night. Granted they had lower prices - as did other hotels for the month of January - but still for a holiday weekend in NYC, the price was right. The room was on the 12th floor and in the back - which meant quiet and solitude. The bed was super comfortable and we slept well. We had trouble getting up in the morning as it may have been too quiet and comfortable. The shower and free extras (shampoo, body wash) were superb. The service was friendly and accommodating. When the hotel receptionist saw that we shared the same last name, she offered to find the best room, and gave us free bottles of water and food. She was super sweet. All in all, we would definitely stay there again - even though I tend to avoid Times Square as much as possible.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: First of all I feel a little mean giving this hotel 3 out of 5 points which by Tripadvisor standards is "average". In fact I'd rate this hotel as "good" but not "very good", which is 4 points. My initial experience with the hotel was less than positive. My husband and I arrived at the hotel at 11.30pm on our first night and they gave us a room on what they call the 2nd floor (1st floor to Europeans). I was immediately nervous as there was scaffolding right outside our window and there was obviously building work going on. I spoke to Harold at reception and he assured me it was "light" building and told me no other guests had complained (not sure I believe that). He wouldn't change our room (apparently they were full) but said he would change it the next day. As predicted it was noisy all night (from the bar next door) and in the morning (from the building site). The room itself was nice (deluxe room) but there were some hairs in the bathroom and the carpet wasn't overly clean. The next day after speaking to reception again, they agreed to change our room to the 15th floor. This room was a million times quieter and slightly bigger and also cleaner (although carpet cleanliness was still an issue). The rest of our stay was really good with no problems. The bed was really comfy, the room was cleaned properly every day and staff were friendly. They also have free WIFI in all rooms which was fantastic. Whether you'll like the location or not depends on what you want to do in NY, We spent most of our time around Soho, West Village, Lower East Side etc, so the location beside Times Sq was particularly advantegous for us and in fact was annoying when we had to walk through it to get to the subway etc. On the other hand, if you want to do more "typically touristy" things, then you might think the location is excellent. Would I stay at Hotel Mela again? Maybe.
reviews.title: Would rate it "good"

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Found the hotel through an online website for a weekend night in Manhattan for my wife's birthday. The hotel is easy to get to and is far enough and close enough to Times Square. The staff was great at check in. The room was nice enough for the price we paid for the location of the hotel. The only negatives were that we did not receive our requested wake up call and the shower is tiny. I would stay here again if I was going to get a hotel in Manhattan.
reviews.title: Pleasant Surprise

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2010, traveled solo
reviews.text: I enjoyed 5 wonderful days at Hotel Mela last week, and I have to say that it's a wonderful hotel. Great location (meaning easy to walk to tons of activities, restaurants, entertainment - as well as a hub for subway travel); a friendly and competent staff (it's hard to pick out one person to mention, as everyone I met from the doormen to cleaning staff went out of their way to be helpful); my room was small, but definitely serviceable for one person. The bathroom was actually large by NY standards, which was a nice surprise. The bed ... let's just say I slept like a baby every night! The furnishings were nice, everything was kept sparkling clean, and the a/c came in handy when the temperature hit 85 one afternoon.
reviews.title: Perfect location, staff, bed...the ideal NY stay!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2008, traveled solo
reviews.text: Based on the terrific reviews on this site, I decided to stay at the Hotel Mela for my recent, 10-night stay in NYC. I was fairly disappointed with my experience. I travel to NYC about 4 times a year and have stayed at quite a few hotels there, some worse, some much better. Yes, the Mela is a boutique hotel but I wouldn't call it trendy, unless a couple of shabby sofas in the small lobby and piped-in electronica deem it as such. Everything about the Mela is tiny, the elevators, the hallways, the rooms themselves, but that was understood from the other reviews. What I didn't expect was how aesthetically mundane the place is. I had an executive suite which was anything but spectacular. Rather, it was dark, drab and lifeless. No view. Flat screen TV was the cheapest I'd ever seen with truly abysmal reception. Bathroom was clean and small, and the brightest spot in the entire hotel. So, overall, the room was clean but unremarkable, forgettable. And over my 10 night stay, here are some of the problems I encountered: Room service food was really awful, and slow too. Ordered a bagel and lox one morning and it took 45 minutes and arrived without creme cheese. When I phoned down, they said they'd send some right up. Arrived 45 minutes later, after another phone call. Another morning, I was awoken at 7am by a knock on my door. My breakfast order had arrived. Too bad I hadn't placed one. Then there was the cleaning staff, the loudest you will ever encounter. They apparently had no regard for the fact that guests might be sleeping, or else wanted to wake them early to get them out of their rooms so they could clean. They marched up and down the halls, spoke to each other on walkie-talkies so loud that I could hear every word, banged doors and hit walls with their supplies. And yet they still managed to forget to refill empty Kleenex, pick up dirty glasses, leave new tea and coffee bags, and even left me with no toilet paper one morning. And speaking of slamming doors, something must be done about this. The doors tend to slam shut if you let go of them before closing them all the way, meaning that if you stay at this hotel, be prepared for lots of slamming doors at all hours from every guest coming or leaving. And on more than one occasion, I heard other guests sneezing and talking in their rooms, even heard someone taking a shower. Basically, this is a very loud hotel. Not soothing in the slightest. Finally, there are the wake up calls I ordered that never came or, inexplicably, came late!?!? How exactly does that happen? And the perfect coda to my experience with the Mela? Went to use the express checkout as I was leaving, and it didn't work. And it sorta made sense because nothing about my stay at the Mela was convenient in any way, shape or form. No, I won't stay there again. Not when there are hotels like the Michelangeo only a stone's-throw away for the same money and superior in EVERY way.
reviews.title: The Disappointing Hotel Mela

reviews.text: This was a great little hotel, smack dab in the middle of Times Square. My husband and I wanted to get away for a night during the week after Christmas and although the city was extremely overcrowded (with people and snow), we really enjoyed our stay at Hotel Mela. I decided to go with this hotel after reading the reviews I saw posted here, and they were essentially right on. The rooms are small, and the lobby is small, but we didn't really care about those things since we didn't plan to spend much time inside. We loved the modern feel, the rooms were very up to date and clean, and the staff was so helpful and courteous. They hald our bags all day long (checkout was at 11 and our train didn't leave until 7pm). Plus, the location can't be beat! What more could you ask for? We'll definitely be returning and highly recommend this hotel to anyone looking for a quick overnight in a really fantastic city!
